Killing Floor. Wow. 

This game is... odd. To say the least. Don't be scared off by its massive amount of professed gore, as in the game image, this is not how the actual game looks or feels. It feels as if it's run off of a very old source engine, but that's not actually a bad thing. It brings back the old Doom-style play-style of things that go in one line and try to kill you. The headshot dynamics are quite fun, and really the only way to handle the higher difficulties of this game. The only drawback, I'd say, is the network connectivity. As the Source engine it's handled on does not work well with multiplayer connections with single private peers, it's often hard to connect even with a person playing the same game. This drawback is almost nullified by the massive amount of multiplayer servers in it itself. The leveling system is quite intricate, even in the bulky non-conforming pattern of previous source engine games. It takes a while to level up, and you have to complete various tasks to do so. A lot of times. The weapons themselves have interesting personalities, and the developers of this game are still updating it as time goes on. All in all, a very good game. I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a wave-by-wave first person shooter that has an incredible community, a sweet old-style feel, and wonderful husks.

Need a game where you can mindlessly kill things alongside 5 other friends? Well this game is for you. Even without getting DLC, there are plenty of guns in the game and different perks to keep you entertained. (Also, sacraficing friends to scrakes is always the way to go)

A wonderful game to play with friends, if you're not averse to some violence. 
They aren't "zombies", they aren't "mutants", they are "experiments" or "Zeds".
You must clear out waves of them or you will die.
If you can't move, you're probably going to die.
Don't make big enemies mad with pistol shots.
If you're a medic, your grenades heal people.
All in all, get this game, play with friends.

4.5 out of 5 apples.
like the holocaust

You never can predict who will survive an apocalypse.  It's an unlikely combination of headshot percentage, situational awareness, and an appropriate hold over one's sense of self-preservation.  A Berzerker can charge fearlessly,  but will likely succumb to friendly fire if too psyched up.  A Firebug will too often find his friends as flammable as the ZEDs.  Most Assaults can't hit the broadside of a barn.  A Support might find the confidence of a shotgun is falsely assured, and weld shut his only chance of escape.  A cool-headed Sharpshooter might find he didn't panic enough, stuck in a corner.  A Medic will learn too late he let too many friends die.  Damn you, Horizine.  You've condemned us all to hell.. well, not me.  I could stare down the gates of Hell with a bolt action rifle, and thanks to Killing Floor, laugh at all other minor cataclysms.  MONEY, MONEY, MONEY! The other survivors will look and dress exactly like me, a ninja in riot gear. Learn to love the endless loops of generic death metal. Insult specimens. Run faster with the knife. Aim for the head.  Let's get to the trader.

I've had this bloody game since long before level 6 was around, or demolotions, back when the level 5 medic could outrun the Patriarch and a raging Scrake/Fleshpound.  I have 360 total hours put into this game, which is extremely high considering my gaming ADD, especially after I complete what I feel I "need" to do.

But that's all just points towards my review on this game.  No matter what other game I buy, try, and enjoy, I always find myself coming back to Killing Floor.  There's just something about the way the game works that draws me in, and I love every minute of it.  The waves mechanic is fun, as well as the co-op play with your friends or even random strangers on a server.  There's plenty of a selection of weapons for each class, and each class has it's own perks.  Not to mention the seasonal promotions they have every year for Summer, Halloween and Christmas.  Tripwire continues to support this game when many developers would have dropped it to make their next big plan come to fruition.  New weapons are introduced every so often, as are new player skins.  This is usually DLC, but, considering the price of the game, is well worth it to customize yourself a little further.

Overall, this game has had me hooked since the day I bought it YEARS ago, and I still play it avidly to this day.  I give this a full 10/10, and I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy shooting zombies (specimens, they're called on here), teamwork, and relentless onslaughts of enemies.  That feeling when you complete a long, suicidal (or harder) game with a pack of friends, man, and you see that achievement flash up on your screen?  One of the best gaming feelings you'll ever get.
Having to get new weapons everytime you die is really a killing chore.

This is one of those hidden gems only Steam can offer. A sort of twitchy brother to Left 4 Dead, Killing Floor has all the things you'd want in a co-op survival horror, the guns feel like they actually pack a punch, the action is constant and intense, and the headshots are beautiful. If you see this little gem go on sale, don't hesitate to snatch it up

Несмотря, на дату выпуска, игра очень атмосферная. Во время игры ты не отвлекаешся на окржающий мир, все твое внимание занимает "куда бежать от этой толпы?!", также очень удачные соундтреки. 
В общем, если у вас на WB лежат деньги и вы незнаете, что покупать Killing Floor лучший вариант!

Years after release, Killing Floor is still one of the best ways to relax and kill zombies. You and your friends can make it as difficult/competitive as you want and there's no shortage of DLC and mods to keep you entertained.

Killing Floor has very solid gunplay and a rewarding perk progression that makes it hard to put down, and there's a fair amount of challenge here, too, if you're looking for it. While it seems most enjoyable when playing with a friend, there's still a lot of fun to be had solo (but it's likely to be more challenging until you get the hang of it). There's a large number of maps bundled with the game, and most--though not all--are designed very well with a nice balance of flow and defendability.

On the downside, I expected a little more enemy variety (not counting model swaps that seem to be seasonal), especially with regards to the Patriarch--who'll you'll fight at the end of every single match. It was also off-putting to me just how much content is paid DLC, and how that fact is right in your face most of the time.  That being said, there's still a lot of content in the base game, and the DLC tends to be just icing on the cake. There's also some free content released every now and then.

Pros:
- Very satisfying combat
- Rewarding skill progression
- Excellent co-op, great solo play
- Good map selection

Cons:
- In-your-face paid DLC
- Limited enemy variety

I love this game.  At first glance I was afraid it was just another Left 4 Dead style game, but it really does manage to distinguish itself.  You fight off waves of enemies, and can weld doors to create defensible areas (though the enemies can break them down).  It's emphasis on defense over mobility really appeals to me. 

 That being said, you DO need to keep moving as well.  The maps are freaking huge and after every wave you have a limited time to get to the store (which changes location each wave), so you end up rushing over and then just finding the nearest place to defend until the next wave is nearly beaten, and then rushing off again.

I like the class system as well.  Commandos, for example, can see invisible enemies and all enemy health bars when no other class can.  Asymetrical gameplay for the win!

I also like the difficulty levels.  Enemies get more health, sure, but the time between waves gets shorter, money gets harder to get, etc etc.  The effect is that on the easiest difficulty you really are just learning the game (no time or money pressure), which is always nice.  Once I got a feel for the mechanics going up in difficulty wasn't that hard (even though I wasn't too high a level yet).  From what I understand the highest difficulty levels require huge amounts of strategy, so I'm not there yet, but it sounds like it'll be a fun end-game.

Killing Floor is a decent game. The gameplay feels slightly choppy like everything else tripwire has to offer, but the atmosphere and variety of weapons/scenarios makes up for it. As far as horror games go, it's fairly enjoyable, with the monsters being visceral and haunting. One of the biggest drawbacks is the lack of an intuitive menu system, one which also makes quickly selecting a weapon in the heat of the moment difficult. Overall, it's a better-than-average horror game that any fan of the genre should try out.
